The **mule deer** (_Odocoileus hemionus_) is a [deer](/wiki/Deer "Deer")
indigenous to western [North America](/wiki/North_America "North America"); it
is named for its ears, which are large like those of the [mule](/wiki/Mule
"Mule"). There are several [subspecies](/wiki/Subspecies "Subspecies"),
including the [black-tailed deer](/wiki/Black-tailed_deer "Black-tailed
deer").[1][3][4][5][6][7]

Unlike the related [white-tailed deer](/wiki/White-tailed_deer "White-tailed
deer") (_Odocoileus virginianus_), mule deer are generally more associated
with the land west of the [Missouri River](/wiki/Missouri_River "Missouri
River"), and more specifically with the [Rocky Mountain](/wiki/Rocky_Mountain
"Rocky Mountain") region of North America. Mule deer have also been introduced
to [Argentina](/wiki/Argentina "Argentina") and [Kauai, Hawaii](/wiki/Kauai
"Kauai").[3]

## Description[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mule_deer&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Description")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Mule_Deer_Sulphur_Springs_Valley_Arizona_2014.jpg/220px-
Mule_Deer_Sulphur_Springs_Valley_Arizona_2014.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mule_Deer_Sulphur_Springs_Valley_Arizona_2014.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mule_Deer_Sulphur_Springs_Valley_Arizona_2014.jpg "Enlarge")

Small herd of mule deer in the [Sulphur Springs
Valley](/wiki/Sulphur_Springs_Valley "Sulphur Springs Valley") of southern
Arizona

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Stotting_mule_deer.jpg/220px-
Stotting_mule_deer.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stotting_mule_deer.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Stotting_mule_deer.jpg "Enlarge")

[Stotting](/wiki/Stotting "Stotting") mule deer

The most noticeable differences between white-tailed and mule deer are the
size of their ears, the color of their tails, and the configuration of their
antlers. In many cases, body size is also a key difference. The mule deer's
tail is black-tipped whereas the whitetail's is not. Mule deer antlers are
bifurcated; they "fork" as they grow, rather than branching from a single main
beam, as is the case with white-tails.

Each spring, a buck's antlers start to regrow almost immediately after the old
antlers are shed. Shedding typically takes place in mid February, with
variations occurring by locale.

Although capable of running, mule deer are often seen
[stotting](/wiki/Stotting "Stotting") (also called pronking), with all four
feet coming down together.

The mule deer is the larger of the two _[Odocoileus](/wiki/Odocoileus
"Odocoileus")_ species on average, with a height of 80–106 cm (31–42 in) at
the shoulders and a nose-to-tail length ranging from 1.2 to 2.1 m (3.9 to 6.9
ft). Of this, the tail may comprise 11.6 to 23 cm (4.6 to 9.1 in). Adult bucks
normally weigh 55–150 kg (121–331 lb), averaging around 92 kg (203 lb),
although trophy specimens may weigh up to 210 kg (460 lb). Does (female deer)
are rather smaller and typically weigh from 43 to 90 kg (95 to 198 lb), with
an average of around 68 kg (150 lb).[8][9][10][11]

Unlike the whitetail, the mule deer does not generally show marked size
variation across its range, although environmental conditions can cause
considerable weight fluctuations in any given population. An exception to this
is the subspecies, the [Sitka black-tailed deer](/wiki/Sitka_deer "Sitka
deer") (_O. h. sitkensis_). This race is markedly smaller than other mule
deer, with an average weight of 54.5 kg (120 lb) and 36 kg (79 lb) in males
and females, respectively.[12]

## Seasonal
behaviors[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mule_deer&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Seasonal behaviors")]

In addition to movements related to available shelter and food, the breeding
cycle is important in understanding deer behavior. The
"[rut](/wiki/Rut_\(mammalian_reproduction\) "Rut \(mammalian reproduction\)")"
or mating season usually begins in the fall as does go into
[estrus](/wiki/Estrus "Estrus") for a period of a few days and males become
more aggressive, competing for mates. Does may mate with more than one buck
and go back into estrus within a month if they did not become pregnant. The
gestation period is about 190–200 days, with fawns born in the spring, staying
with their mothers during the summer and being weaned in the fall after about
60–75 days. Mule deer females usually give birth to two fawns, although if it
is their first time having a fawn, they often have just one.[13]

A buck's antlers fall off during the winter, to grow again in preparation for
the next season's rut. The annual cycle of antler growth is regulated by
changes in the length of the day.[13] For a guide to identify the sex and age
class of Rocky Mountain mule deer at various seasons see S1 File.[14] For more
information see the [main article on deer](/wiki/Deer#Antlers "Deer").

The size of mule deer groups follow a marked seasonal pattern. Groups are
smallest during fawning season (June and July in Saskatchewan and Alberta) and
largest in early gestation (winter; February and March in Saskatchewan and
Alberta).[14]

Besides humans, the three leading predators of mule deer are
[coyotes](/wiki/Coyote "Coyote"), [gray wolves](/wiki/Gray_wolf "Gray wolf"),
and [cougars](/wiki/Cougar "Cougar"). [Bobcats](/wiki/Bobcat "Bobcat"),
[wolverines](/wiki/Wolverine "Wolverine"), [American black
bears](/wiki/American_black_bear "American black bear"), and [brown
bears](/wiki/Brown_bear "Brown bear") may prey upon adult deer, but most often
only attack fawns or infirm specimens or eat the deer after it has died
naturally. Bears and smaller sized carnivores are typically opportunistic
feeders, and would pose little threat to a strong, healthy mule deer.[9]

## Diet and foraging
behaviors[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mule_deer&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Diet and foraging behaviors")]

![File:Mule Deer foraging at Okanagan Mountain Provincial
Park.webm](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Mule_Deer_foraging_at_Okanagan_Mountain_Provincial_Park.webm/220px
--Mule_Deer_foraging_at_Okanagan_Mountain_Provincial_Park.webm.jpg)[Play
media](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/0c/Mule_Deer_foraging_at_Okanagan_Mountain_Provincial_Park.webm
"Play media")

[](/wiki/File:Mule_Deer_foraging_at_Okanagan_Mountain_Provincial_Park.webm
"Enlarge")

Mule deer foraging on a late winter morning at Okanagan Mountain Provincial
Park

Kufleld et al. (1973) analyzed 99 studies of mule deer diets and found that
some 788 species of plants were eaten by mule deer, and mule deer diets vary
greatly depending on the season, geographic region, year, and elevation.[15]
Kufeld, et al. (1973) gave the following data for [Rocky
Mountain](/wiki/Rocky_Mountain "Rocky Mountain") mule deer diets:[16]

| Shrubs and trees | [Forbs](/wiki/Forb "Forb") | Grasses and grasslikes  
---|---|---|---  
Winter | 74% | 15% | 11% (varies 0-53%)  
Spring | 49% | 25% | 26% (varies 4-64%)  
Summer | 49% | 46% (varies 3-77%) | 3% (varies 0-22%)  
Fall | 60% | 30% (varies 2-78%) | 9% (varies 0-24%)  
  
Anthony & Smith (1977) found that the diets of mule deer are very similar to
those of whitetail deer in areas where they coexist.[15] Mule deer are
intermediate feeders rather than pure [browsers](/wiki/Browsing_\(herbivory\)
"Browsing \(herbivory\)") or [grazers](/wiki/Grazing "Grazing"); they
predominantly browse, but also eat [forb](/wiki/Forb "Forb") vegetation, small
amounts of grass, and where available, tree or shrub fruits such as
[beans](/wiki/Bean "Bean"),
[pods](/wiki/Glossary_of_plant_morphology#Fruit_types "Glossary of plant
morphology"), [nuts](/wiki/Nut_\(fruit\) "Nut \(fruit\)") (including
[acorns](/wiki/Acorn "Acorn"), and [berries](/wiki/Berry "Berry").[15][16]

Mule deer readily adapt to agricultural products and landscape
plantings.[17][18] In the [Sierra Nevada range](/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_\(U.S.\)
"Sierra Nevada \(U.S.\)"), mule deer depend on the lichen _[Bryoria
fremontii](/wiki/Bryoria_fremontii "Bryoria fremontii")_ as a winter food
source.[19]:2:4

The most common plant species consumed by mule deer are:

  * Among trees and shrubs: _[Artemisia tridentata](/wiki/Artemisia_tridentata "Artemisia tridentata")_ (big sagebrush), _[Cercocarpus ledifolius](/wiki/Cercocarpus_ledifolius "Cercocarpus ledifolius")_ (curlleaf mountain mahogany), _[Cercocarpus montanus](/wiki/Cercocarpus_montanus "Cercocarpus montanus")_ (true mountain mahogany), _[Cowania mexicana](/wiki/Cowania_mexicana "Cowania mexicana")_ (Mexican cliffrose), _[Populus tremuloides](/wiki/Populus_tremuloides "Populus tremuloides")_ (quaking aspen), _[Purshia tridentata](/wiki/Purshia_tridentata "Purshia tridentata")_ (antelope bitterbrush), _[Quercus gambelii](/wiki/Quercus_gambelii "Quercus gambelii")_ (Gambel oak), and _[Rhus trilobata](/wiki/Rhus_trilobata "Rhus trilobata")_ (skunkbush sumac).[16]
  * Among forbs: _[Achillea millefolium](/wiki/Achillea_millefolium "Achillea millefolium")_ (western yarrow), _[Antennaria](/wiki/Antennaria "Antennaria")_ sp. (pussytoes), _[Artemisia frigida](/wiki/Artemisia_frigida "Artemisia frigida")_ (fringed sagebrush), _[Artemisia ludoviciana](/wiki/Artemisia_ludoviciana "Artemisia ludoviciana")_ (Louisiana sagewort), [Aster](/wiki/Aster_\(genus\) "Aster \(genus\)") spp., _[Astragalus](/wiki/Astragalus "Astragalus")_ sp. (milkvetch), _[Balsamorhiza sagittata](/wiki/Balsamorhiza_sagittata "Balsamorhiza sagittata")_ (arrowleaf balsamroot), _[Cirsium](/wiki/Cirsium "Cirsium")_ sp. (thistle), _[Erigeron](/wiki/Erigeron "Erigeron")_ spp. (fleabane), _[Geranium](/wiki/Geranium "Geranium")_ sp., _[Lactuca serriola](/wiki/Lactuca_serriola "Lactuca serriola")_ (prickly lettuce), _[Lupinus](/wiki/Lupinus "Lupinus")_ spp. (lupine), _Medicago sativa_ ([alfalfa](/wiki/Alfalfa "Alfalfa")), _[Penstemon](/wiki/Penstemon "Penstemon")_ spp., _[Phlox](/wiki/Phlox "Phlox")_ spp., _[Polygonum](/wiki/Polygonum "Polygonum")_ sp. (knotweed/smartweed), _[Potentilla](/wiki/Potentilla "Potentilla")_ spp. (cinquefoil), _[Taraxacum officinale](/wiki/Taraxacum_officinale "Taraxacum officinale")_ (dandelion), _[Tragopogon dubius](/wiki/Tragopogon_dubius "Tragopogon dubius")_ (western salsify), _Trifolium_ sp. ([clover](/wiki/Clover "Clover")), and _[Vicia americana](/wiki/Vicia_americana "Vicia americana")_ (American vetch).[16]
  * Among grasses and grasslike species: _[Agropyron](/wiki/Agropyron "Agropyron")_ , _[Elymus](/wiki/Elymus_\(plant\) "Elymus \(plant\)")_ (wheatgrasses), _[Elytrigia](/wiki/Elytrigia "Elytrigia")_ , _[Pascopyrum](/wiki/Pascopyrum "Pascopyrum")_ sp. ([wheatgrasses](/wiki/Wheatgrass "Wheatgrass")), _[Pseudoroegneria spicatum](/wiki/Pseudoroegneria_spicatum "Pseudoroegneria spicatum")_ (bluebunch wheatgrass), _[Bromus tectorum](/wiki/Bromus_tectorum "Bromus tectorum")_ (cheatgrass), _[Carex](/wiki/Carex "Carex")_ spp. (sedge), _[Festuca idahoensis](/wiki/Festuca_idahoensis "Festuca idahoensis")_ (Idaho fescue), _[Poa fendleriana](/wiki/Poa_fendleriana "Poa fendleriana")_ ([muttongrass](/wiki/Muttongrass "Muttongrass")), _[Poa pratensis](/wiki/Poa_pratensis "Poa pratensis")_ (Kentucky bluegrass), and other _[Poa](/wiki/Poa "Poa")_ spp. (bluegrass).[16]

Mule deer have also been known to eat [ricegrass](/wiki/Ricegrass
"Ricegrass"), [gramagrass](/wiki/Gramagrass "Gramagrass"),
[bromegrass](/wiki/Bromegrass "Bromegrass"), and
[needlegrass](/wiki/Needlegrass "Needlegrass"), as well as [antelope
brush](/wiki/Antelope_brush "Antelope brush"), [bearberry](/wiki/Bearberry
"Bearberry"), [bitter cherry](/wiki/Bitter_cherry "Bitter cherry"),
[bitterbrush](/wiki/Bitterbrush "Bitterbrush"), [black
oak](/wiki/Quercus_velutina "Quercus velutina"), [California
buckeye](/wiki/California_buckeye "California buckeye"),
[ceanothus](/wiki/Ceanothus "Ceanothus"), [cedar](/wiki/Cedrus "Cedrus"),
[cliffrose](/wiki/Cliffrose "Cliffrose"), [cottonwood](/wiki/Populus
"Populus"), [creek dogwood](/wiki/Creek_dogwood "Creek dogwood"), [creeping
barberry](/wiki/Creeping_barberry "Creeping barberry"),
[dogwood](/wiki/Dogwood "Dogwood"), [Douglas fir](/wiki/Douglas_fir "Douglas
fir"), [elderberry](/wiki/Elderberry "Elderberry"), [fendlera](/wiki/Fendlera
"Fendlera"), [goldeneye](/wiki/Viguiera "Viguiera"), [holly-leaf
buckthrorn](/wiki/Holly-leaf_buckthrorn "Holly-leaf buckthrorn"), [jack
pine](/wiki/Jack_pine "Jack pine"), [knotweed](/wiki/Knotweed "Knotweed"),
[kohleria](/wiki/Kohleria "Kohleria"), [manzanita](/wiki/Manzanita
"Manzanita"), [mesquite](/wiki/Mesquite "Mesquite"), [oak](/wiki/Oak "Oak"),
[pine](/wiki/Pine "Pine"), [rabbitbrush](/wiki/Rabbitbrush "Rabbitbrush"),
[ragweed](/wiki/Ragweed "Ragweed"), [redberry](/wiki/Rhamnus_crocea "Rhamnus
crocea"), [scrub oak](/wiki/Scrub_oak "Scrub oak"),
[serviceberry](/wiki/Serviceberry "Serviceberry") (including [Pacific
serviceberry](/wiki/Pacific_serviceberry "Pacific serviceberry")), [Sierra
juniper](/wiki/Sierra_juniper "Sierra juniper"), [silktassel](/wiki/Silktassel
"Silktassel"), [snowberry](/wiki/Snowberry "Snowberry"),
[stonecrop](/wiki/Stonecrop "Stonecrop"), [sunflower](/wiki/Sunflower
"Sunflower"), [tesota](/wiki/Tesota "Tesota"),
[thimbleberry](/wiki/Thimbleberry "Thimbleberry"), [turbinella
oak](/wiki/Turbinella_oak "Turbinella oak"), [velvet elder](/wiki/Velvet_elder
"Velvet elder"), [western chokecherry](/wiki/Western_chokecherry "Western
chokecherry"), [wild cherry](/wiki/Prunus_serotina "Prunus serotina"), and
[wild oats](/wiki/Chasmanthium_latifolium "Chasmanthium latifolium").[20]
Where available, mule deer also eat a variety of wild
[mushrooms](/wiki/Mushroom "Mushroom"), which are most abundant in late summer
and fall in the southern Rocky Mountains; mushrooms provide moisture, protein,
phosphorus, and potassium.[15][20]

Humans sometimes engage in supplemental feeding efforts in severe winters in
an attempt to avoid mule deer starvation. Wildlife agencies discourage most
such efforts, which may cause harm to mule deer populations by spreading
disease (such as [tuberculosis](/wiki/Tuberculosis "Tuberculosis") and
[chronic wasting disease](/wiki/Chronic_wasting_disease "Chronic wasting
disease")) when deer congregate for feed; disrupting migratory patterns; and
causing overpopulation of local mule deer populations and overbrowsing of
shrubs and [forbs](/wiki/Forb "Forb").[21] Supplemental feeding efforts are
appropriate when carefully conducted under limited circumstances, but to be
successful, the feeding must begin early in the severe winter, before poor
range conditions and severe weather cause malnourishment or starvation, and
must be continued until range conditions can support the herd.[21]

Mule deer are variably gregarious, with a large proportion of solitary
individuals (35 to 64%) and small groups (groups with ≤5 deer, 50 to
78%).[22][23] Reported [mean group size](/wiki/Group_size_measures "Group size
measures") measurements are three to five and [typical group
size](/wiki/Group_size_measures "Group size measures") (i.e. crowding) is
about seven.[14][24]

## Nutrition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mule_deer&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Nutrition")]

Mule deer are [ruminants](/wiki/Ruminants "Ruminants"), meaning they employ a
nutrient acquisition strategy of fermenting plant material before digesting
it. Deer consuming high-fiber, low-starch diets require less food than those
consuming high-starch, low-fiber diets. Rumination time also increases when
deer consume high-fiber, low-starch diets which allows for increased nutrient
acquisition due to greater length of fermentation.[25] Because some of the
subspecies of mule deer are migratory, they encounter variable habitats and
forage quality throughout the year.[26] Forages consumed in the summer are
higher in digestible components (i.e. proteins, starches, sugars, and
hemicellulose) than those consumed in the winter. The average gross energy
content of the consumed forage material is 4.5 kcal/g.[27] Due to fluctuations
in forage quality and availability, mule deer fat storage varies throughout
the year, with the most fat stored in October, which is depleted throughout
the winter to the lowest levels of fat storage in March. Changes in hormone
levels are indications of physiological adjustments to the changes in the
habitat. Total body fat is a measure of the individual’s energy reserves while
thyroid hormone concentrations are a metric to determine the deer’s ability to
utilize the fat reserves. Triiodothryionine (T3) hormone is directly involved
with basal metabolic rate and thermoregulation.[28]

## Taxonomy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mule_deer&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Taxonomy")]

The mule deer can be divided into two main groups: The mule deer (_[sensu
stricto](/wiki/Sensu_stricto "Sensu stricto")_) and the [black-tailed
deer](/wiki/Black-tailed_deer "Black-tailed deer"). The first group includes
all subspecies, except _[O. h. columbianus](/wiki/Black-tailed_Deer "Black-
tailed Deer")_ and _[O. h. sitkensis](/wiki/Sitka_Deer "Sitka Deer")_ , which
are in the black-tailed deer group.[3] The two main groups have been treated
as separate species, but they [hybridize](/wiki/Hybrid_\(biology\) "Hybrid
\(biology\)"), and virtually all recent authorities treat the mule deer and
black-tailed deer as [conspecific](/wiki/Conspecific
"Conspecific").[1][3][4][5][7][29] It appears the mule deer
[evolved](/wiki/Evolved "Evolved") from the black-tailed deer.[7] Despite
this, the [mtDNA](/wiki/MtDNA "MtDNA") of the white-tailed deer and mule deer
are similar, but differ from that of the black-tailed deer.[7] This may be the
result of [introgression](/wiki/Introgression "Introgression"), although
hybrids between the mule deer and white-tailed deer are rare in the wild
(apparently more common locally in [West Texas](/wiki/West_Texas "West
Texas")), and the hybrid [survival rate](/wiki/Survival_rate "Survival rate")
is low even in captivity.[6][7] Many claims of observations of wild hybrids
are not legitimate, as identification based on external features is
complicated.[6]

### Subspecies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mule_deer&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Subspecies")]

Some authorities have recognized _O. h. crooki_ as a [senior
synonym](/wiki/Senior_synonym "Senior synonym") of _O. h. eremicus_ , but the
[type specimen](/wiki/Type_specimen "Type specimen") of the former is a
[hybrid](/wiki/Hybrid_\(biology\) "Hybrid \(biology\)") between the mule deer
and white-tailed deer, so the name _O. h. crooki_ is invalid.[3][30]
Additionally, the validity of _O. h. inyoensis_ has been questioned, and the
two insular _O. h. cerrosensis_ and _O. h. sheldoni_ may be
[synonyms](/wiki/Synonym_\(taxonomy\) "Synonym \(taxonomy\)") of _O. h.
eremicus_ or _O. h. peninsulae_.[29]

The 10 valid subspecies based on the third edition of _[Mammal Species of the
World](/wiki/Mammal_Species_of_the_World "Mammal Species of the World")_
are:[3]

  * Mule deer (_[sensu stricto](/wiki/Sensu_stricto "Sensu stricto")_) group: 
    * _[O. h. californicus](/wiki/California_mule_deer "California mule deer")_ – [California](/wiki/California "California") mule deer
    * _[O. h. cerrosensis](/wiki/Cedros_Island_mule_deer "Cedros Island mule deer")_ – Cedros/Cerros Island mule deer ([Cedros Island](/wiki/Cedros_Island "Cedros Island"))
    * _O. h. eremicus_ – desert/burro mule deer ([Lower Colorado River Valley](/wiki/Lower_Colorado_River_Valley "Lower Colorado River Valley"); northwest Mexico, southeastern California, and [Arizona](/wiki/Arizona "Arizona"))
    * _O. h. fuliginatus_ – southern mule deer (southernmost California and [Baja California](/wiki/Baja_California "Baja California"))
    * _O. h. hemionus_ – [Rocky Mountain](/wiki/Rocky_Mountain "Rocky Mountain") mule deer (western and central North America)
    * _O. h. inyoensis_ – [Inyo](/wiki/Inyo_County,_California "Inyo County, California") mule deer ([Sierra Nevada](/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_\(U.S.\) "Sierra Nevada \(U.S.\)"), California)
    * _O. h. peninsulae_ – Peninsula mule deer ([Baja California Sur](/wiki/Baja_California_Sur "Baja California Sur"))
    * _O. h. sheldoni_ – Tiburon Island mule deer ([Tiburon Island](/wiki/Tiburon_Island "Tiburon Island"))
  * Black-tailed deer group: 
    * _[O. h. columbianus](/wiki/Black-tailed_deer "Black-tailed deer")_ – black-tailed deer ([Pacific Northwest](/wiki/Pacific_Northwest "Pacific Northwest") and [Northern California](/wiki/Northern_California "Northern California") regions)
    * _[O. h. sitkensis](/wiki/Sitka_deer "Sitka deer")_ – [Sitka](/wiki/Sitka,_Alaska "Sitka, Alaska") black-tailed deer (coastal area and islands off western [British Columbia](/wiki/British_Columbia "British Columbia"))
